Hears this sort of... Once, the Buddha was staying at the monastery in the country of Kapilavastu. In the morning
he adjusted his robes and called to Ä€nanda:
You invite the wise ones, the assembly of evildoers, the unattached, the followers of traces, and so forth. Today there will be a superior question about the essentials.
Thereupon, Ä€nanda received the order and immediately proclaimed the TathÄgata's teaching to the four groups of people.

At that time, there was an assembly of evildoers, unattached, and followers of traces, a total of five million people, who went to where the TathÄgata was, bowed their heads to the ground, and then stepped aside to stay.

There were also the assembly of virtuous women, the assembly of those who abandoned evil, and the ordinary women in the country who followed the virtuous women, a total of fourteen million people, who went to where the TathÄgata was, bowed their heads to the ground, withdrew from their seats, and sat down.
There were also 800 million and 20,000 bright scholars who came to where the TathÄgata was, bowed their heads to the ground, and stood there respectfully.
There were also 40,000 scholars who practiced precepts at home. They came together, bowed their heads to the ground, and then each stood back.

The Buddha, with his majestic spiritual power, moved the bright scholars and the celestial beings above in the Buddha lands of the ten directions. Those who were supposed to attain enlightenment and those who were supposed to give rise to the intention [for enlightenment], a total of 800 million people, all flew to where the Buddha was, bowed their heads to the ground, and lined up in the sky.

There were also 12 celestial generals, leading 400,000 officials and subordinates, who came to where the Buddha was, bowed their heads to the ground, and then each took their place to stand and serve to the Buddha's left and right.
On that day, the assembly gathered in the time it takes to eat a meal, and all came to where the Buddha was. The Buddha then told them to sit down.
Those with physical bodies who had not yet attained the four bases of supernatural power should all go to the mats;

The wise ones and celestial beings from the ten directions, whose bodies were light, or who had already attained spiritual powers, all rose up in the sky and sat on natural seats. Each had transformed flower canopies, arranged in a wonderful way, all created by the Buddha's majestic transformations.

The wise ones who came and sat in the assembly were all of subtle conduct, pure minds and mouths, and upheld various precepts. The three defilements, six afflictions, and five hindrances had already been removed. The various afflictions, mixed defilements, doubts, entangled views, ignorance, and the twelve links of dependent origination had all been severed.
Pure like the moon and flowers, each followed the worldly customs and established names accordingly.

There were wise ones named King of Non-Defilement, next named Venerable Light and Glory, next named Wisdom Like a Mountain, next named Great Pure Flower, next named Transforming Roots and Fragrance, next named
Moon Essence Radiance, next named Light of Excellence, next named Upright Unlawful, next
named Good among the Good, next named Kunlun Light, next named Sunlight Essence, next

next named Virtue Pervading Everywhere, next named Universally Disciplined and Agile, next named Respectfully Upright Conduct,
next named Benevolent and Kind, next named Wisdom Creation, next named Dispersing Knots,

King, next named World Protector, next named World Guide, next named Great Power,

At that time, there was a noble youth named Sumati, who came to the Buddha with five hundred of his peers, each with an attendant holding an umbrella, to the place of the Tathagata. They bowed at the feet of the Tathagata, stood up, and looked around. The four directions were very crowded. Looking up at the sky, they were all superior people. The Heavenly Honored One was seated, upright and dignified. He thought to himself:
Today, with great blessings, I have encountered this assembly. I wish to provide food and drink for one day.
Considering what I have, I cannot provide it. If the offering is not equal, it is not a gift. What should I do?
Then the Buddha knew what Sumati was thinking and said to him:
Young man, welcome!
Have you heard the Dharma exhortation?
He said:
I have not yet understood. When I stand up, I can be called wise.
Not considering little or much, having something to hope for, can be called giving.
The one you just thought of, the TathÄgata is here. What difficulty is there that cannot be accomplished?
The TathÄgata can make the unaccomplished accomplished, the insufficient sufficient, always sufficient, always accomplishing what is to be done. This is called the TathÄgata.

What the TathÄgata accomplishes does not depend on clothing, food, or sensual pleasures, but rather on perfect precepts. He does not listen to the delusions of the six afflictions and five hindrances. He does not think of family happiness, does not have the notion of the four foods, and also has no adornments of clothing and headwear.
Dwelling in the midst of the idea of permanence, he knows the truth of impermanence;
Dwelling in the land of delusion and happiness, he realizes the opposite of definite suffering.
In the chamber of craving existence, he illuminates the basis of emptiness and nonexistence;
In the body of accepting existence, he clarifies the non-self of the true self.
Without self, without action, without conditions, without attachment, this is the accomplishment of the TathÄgata.
Thereupon, SubhÅ«ti heard the Heavenly Honored One's teaching, his mind delighted and knots unraveled. His body felt light and exuberant, and he said:

I was originally not wise, bound in a chain of twelve, my mind arose and fell into darkness, falling into the three flows of the mundane world. What I have heard today is an unprecedented Dharma. I wish to uphold it with my body, as the Heavenly Venerable teaches, all delighting in the wonderful Dharma.
And he then praised:
The most honored among gods and humans, the TathÄgata is supreme;
With compassionate encouragement and rescue, he equally bestows the three realms.
Those of inferior faculties, poor practices, he gathers them with the wealth of the Dharma;
Causing all delusions to be explained without doubt.
The body is honored and endowed with nobility, with unparalleled excellent characteristics;
Extending the mind for the sake of others, expounding the Dharma endlessly.
The myriad streams of profound wisdom flow like a melting mountain;
The Dharma's grace extends to the three realms, spreading to the ten directions.
The marks of a great person are complete, with precious wisdom fully endowed;
Wherever the Dharma appears, he guides those who have not yet attained.
The wisdom illuminates the foolish and the dark, leading them to the pure place;
I wish to personally take refuge and reach the other shore.
Then, having finished praising, Sumati knelt for a long time and said to the World-Honored One:
Please fulfill my original intention. Today I have prepared a meal, only begging for your compassionate acceptance.
The World-Honored One remained silent, as was his usual way;
Sumati respectfully stood there, thinking he had not yet been granted permission.
Then Ä€nanda opened up and said to him:
The World-Honored One's silence is his way of accepting you.
When Sumati heard this, his mind was filled with joy. He bowed and left. He stayed outside the gate and sent someone in to report, saying:
Now, according to what I have, it is enough to provide food for two thousand people. I wish to inform the World-Honored One, so he knows it is like this.
Ä€nanda then reported to the Buddha, fully conveying what Sumati had said.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
Your words are well-spoken. Send her back to prepare offerings to the best of her abilities. The Buddha will go with the great assembly, so don't worry about not having enough.
Ä€nanda went out and told SuyÄma everything as the Buddha had instructed.
Ä€nanda said again:
Virtuous one, you may return. Do not have two thoughts, fearing there will not be enough.
Wherever the Buddha's spiritual power reaches, nothing is incomplete.
SuyÄma then bowed to Ä€nanda and returned.
Returning home, he ordered his wife, children, and all the household members, saying:
The one I have invited is called the Heavenly Honored One.
He is spiritually wondrous and all-encompassing, and is the Omniscient One.
If one offers him a single item, one will receive blessings for world after world, without end.
Moreover, he can liberate people and untie the knots of attachment.
You all should be reverent and pure in offering food and drink, fully preparing various delicacies, making them extremely delicious.
The family members and servants each did their utmost with utmost sincerity:
The Venerable One is difficult to encounter, appearing in the world only once in many eons. What should be done should be done purely.
At that time, there was a wise person in the assembly named Li Pan Zhong You.
The Buddha told him to act together with Shan Ming to provide for the great assembly.
Then, the twelve celestial kings, the four heavenly kings, and the powerful dragon kings, receiving the Buddha's instructions, all followed the wise person Li Pan Zhong You to assist him.
Upon arrival, they respectfully said to Shan Ming:
Virtuous one, with diligent mind, the Buddha has sent us to come and help.
Shan Ming then went forward to pay respects to the wise person and the celestial kings, respectfully declining and saying:

Having troubled the superior ones, the provisions for two thousand people have already been prepared. The great assembly is about to arrive, but I fear this small dwelling will not suffice. What should be done?
Thereupon, the wise person Li Pan Zhong You and the celestial kings replied:
Do not worry.
They looked to the left and right, and the house naturally became long, wide, tall, and grand, like a heavenly palace.
Under the house, there were then thousands of millions of seats, all the shapes of various treasures, the color of dark-blue lapis lazuli.
The beds and seats in the room were also like this.
In the time it takes to snap one's fingers, there were then hundreds of thousands of millions of people's food and drink, all sufficient.
They burned various famous fragrances and hung silk banners. The path they walked on then became wide and flat.
The color was like crystal. The trees were arranged in rows, and the natural music had a solemn and harmonious sound, with the sound of the Dharma, the eight kinds of Shakra and Brahma.
At that time, the wise one who accomplished all things and the kings of the various celestial gods returned to where the Buddha was.
Good and clear vision saw this great change, and with shock and joy, they came to the World-Honored One and said:
Receiving the Buddha's great kindness, what has been set up is already complete.
I only wish that the assembly would deign to condescend to the honored spirit.
The Buddha then ordered the six million people including the Virtuous One of No Filth to lead the way, some walking through the sky.
The Buddha was in the center, followed by the rest.
When the Tathagata left the gate, the earth trembled, the gods scattered flowers, burned various famous incense, and then played the best music, singing praises as they followed.

When they arrived, they all sat down. The heavenly kings then assisted in offering the food. The Buddha recited the vow, and after eating, they were all satisfied. The food did not disappear, and the bowls were still full as before.
The Virtuous One of Good Understanding alone said to himself:
The majestic transformations of the Heavenly Venerable are vast like this. After finishing the meal and washing the bowls, I will ask about this meaning.
After washing the bowls, in the time it takes to extend and bend one's arm, the Buddha and the great assembly suddenly returned and sat in the monastery.
Then the Virtuous One of Good Understanding sighed again, saying:
The Heavenly Venerable is truly divine and wondrous, rarely seen or heard of in the world;
The changes are extraordinary and unique,ğŸ”½Those who see it are delighted.
Observing it carefully, it is very wonderful and elegant, The changes shown are difficult to match;
Without doing anything, it is complete by itself, Without toil, it satisfies the multitude.
Without speaking, it naturally acts, Without instruction, it acts by itself;
Without doing anything, it encounters doing, What will this virtue lead to?
What arts and methods did you practice in the past, That you were born with this glory?
What roots of virtue have you accumulated, To attain this lofty and venerable status?
Please have compassion for the poor, Open up and bestow the wealth of the Dharma;
Resolve the knots in the mind, Release them without any remaining doubts.
Having praised, Sumati further moved aside, joined his palms, and said:
Not far from here, there is a village called Blissful Security.
That is the place where the Buddha showed compassion just now.
I always enjoyed learning in that gathering, learning worldly etiquette, the rules of ancient kings, and the methods of sages and immortals.
I first heard that the Celestial Honored One was recently in this country, and my thoughts and imagination gave rise to dreams that vaguely resembled him.
The disciple of the Celestial Honored One named ÅšÄriputra often came to my house and spoke the Dharma for me.
The Dharma was extremely profound and wonderful, and I longed to hear it. Although my heart was delighted, I still felt confused.

Today I came lightly to pay homage to the Buddha, the Celestial Honored One, and to observe the Way and Dharma. What should be practiced, upon seeing it, my heart was delighted, like seeing light in the dark.
I wanted to prepare a meal, and thus obtained an extraordinary question. What I have is meager, and I dare not speak out.

The Celestial Honored One's spiritual powers welcomed and knew my mind. The power of the Way assisted me, and the bedding, seats, and food were suddenly prepared. After the meal, the utensils were full as before.
What kind of transformation is this?
The spiritual wonder is like this!
Furthermore, observing the World-Honored One's thirty-two marks, each one is excellent, never tiring of beholding them.
When walking, he is orderly, neither slow nor fast;
When sitting, he sits in the middle, neither too far forward nor too far back;
His speech has eight qualities, neither lax nor hurried.
His words establish the Dharma and Vinaya, and his clear admonitions are like the sun, causing all beings to receive the grace of blessings.
What practices did he cultivate in the past to be born with this?

Furthermore, seeing the World-Honored One's feet not touching the ground, with the wheel marks clearly arranged, upright and majestic like a painting, his body light and free, manifesting transformations everywhere, what practices are these, that he has this in the world?
I wish you would explain it, so that I may know the beginning and end.
Then the Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
As you have asked, the TathÄgata will fully expound it. Be attentive and receive it all without forgetting.
Sumati then said:
I will receive the teaching.
The Buddha said:

I originally practiced the six virtues, not neglecting them in life after life, and thus I attained Buddhahood. I can transform at will, do whatever I want, become omniscient, and understand everything.
He said:
What are the six virtues?
He said:
Extensive giving, extensive precepts, extensive patience, extensive diligence, extensive single-mindedness, and extensive wisdom.
Subhuti said to the Buddha:
What is meant by extensive giving?
The Buddha said:

One who practices the Way should first know that the body is not a real thing, but is formed from the four elements. Bones and flesh are impure, and should all be abandoned and returned to their origins, not allowed to remain.
The body is not mine, and wealth is not mine to possess. The mind has no form and is truly impermanent.
It is bound by conditioned causes and conditions, and therefore there is bodily action. The body is impermanent and will also decay.
Contemplating in this way, one establishes four beliefs.
The inner body, the outer body, the myriad things of heaven and earth, are all impermanent, and will eventually return to destruction and ruin, to be abandoned, scattered, dissolved, and melted away.
Once this faith is established, then contemplate the non-substance of the body, and the non-substance of things. One will then be able to give freely and satisfy others.
Moreover, the Dharma offering leads to the transformation of the ignorant, and is therefore called extensive giving.
What is meant by extensive precepts?
He said:
Extensive precepts refer to being able to restrain the three calamities of the body, guard the four faults of the mouth, and examine the three evils of the mind.

As for bodily conduct, if one sees all sentient beings, crawling and wriggling creatures, one should have compassion and pity for them, release and save them, and according to their water and land, return and settle them.
If one sees precious treasures, soft and smooth things that are pleasing to the mind, even if one is poor and suffering, one should subdue one's mind and not greedily take them.
And when seeing fine colors and powdered cosmetics, one inwardly contemplates the foul smell of decaying pus and blood. These are the three precepts of the body.

As for the practice of speech, if others inflict the four faults upon oneself, one then becomes aware of the faults of speech. One repays them with kind words and gentle speech, speaks with sincerity and without embellishment, and responds to transform them, causing them to turn and follow oneself. These are the four precepts of speech.
As for the practice of the mind, one's mind cultivates wisdom, contemplates birth and death, always abides in the place of wisdom, and is not confused or deluded.
Moreover, one deeply enters the essentials of the path and emptiness, distinctly understands the true teachings without any doubts or difficulties.
Seeing goodness, one encourages it. When accomplished, one rejoices on behalf of others. These are the three precepts of the mind.

Therefore, at the beginning of practicing the path, one first observes the ten precepts. Having been able to do so oneself, one also transforms others. One is diligent without slacking off, practices without resting, and has no thoughts of laziness or weariness. Therefore, it is called the extensive precepts.
What is meant by extensive patience?
It is said:
Extensive patience means that if someone scolds me, I consider that the sound comes from the voice and reaches here, but upon examination, it has no form;
The original sound comes from the mind and intention, but upon examining the mind and intention, they too have no form.

Observing what the mind relies on, it relies on the four elements. The four elements return to their origins, and then they also have no name, are neither me nor others, are neither male nor female, and are neither old nor young, and upon examination, they have no master.
Where shame and humiliation exist, they have no form and are established as words.
In the two non-existences, there are also no forms. Considering these three, they are empty and do not exist.

The wise person scatters the mind and contemplates in this way, then anger does not arise. Using emptiness to endure emptiness, and also in the midst of various evils, one endures and does not commit them.
Facing them without arising, restraining the mind and subduing the intention, the body itself is able to be so, and also teaching others, this is called extensive patience.
What is called extensive vigor?
Reducing the amount of food, not relishing flavors;
Except for sleeping, they should be mindful day and night.
Dedicating themselves to the Way, they should practice the various precepts.
Whether sitting or standing, they should not lose proper deportment. They should cultivate the practice of non-transgression in their minds;
They should diligently recite the essential teachings of the Way, diligently receiving them during the day and practicing walking meditation at night.
Their speech should accord with the precepts, and their body, speech, and mind should be in harmony. They should rely on mindfulness of the Dharma and not be apart from the scriptures.
Sitting and expounding widely, their minds should not be troubled. Teaching the ignorant and stubborn, they should not be lazy or weary.
Going against their minds and thoughts, they should attain single-minded concentration. Having mastered it themselves, they should also teach others.
This is called extensive vigor.
What is meant by extensive single-mindedness?
Serving one's parents with filial piety is to unify one's mind;
Respecting teachers and friends is to unify one's mind;
Cutting off desires and distancing oneself from worldly affairs is to unify one's mind;
Entering the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment is to unify one's mind;
In empty and quiet places, they unify their minds;
In the midst of many disturbances, they unify their minds;
In places of much desire, much contention, much activity, and much vexation, they unify their minds;
In the face of praise, slander, gain, loss, good, and evil, they remain unmoved and unify their minds;
They unify their minds in counting breaths to enter meditation, abandoning the six [sense objects] and abiding in purity.
They themselves are able to practice and also teach others. This is called the extensive single-mindedness.
What is meant by extensive wisdom?
He said:

The wise one, in accordance with the body he receives, has the three kinds of pain, six afflictions, five hindrances and defilements, sixty-two kinds of thoughts of sinking and pondering, eighty-eight kinds of difficult-to-understand bonds, and eighteen hundred kinds of painful wounds.
If it is these kinds of things, then with wisdom, one clearly understands each one.
Observe their arising, examine their ceasing;
View their illnesses, select the appropriate medicine.
Having summarized the essentials, one's body does not violate the precepts, and the mind does not enter the mundane.
Dwelling in the midst of love for the assembly, the mind is in the treasury of the factors of the path;
Relying on the house of the six afflictions, the mind is in the hall of the six purities;
Dwelling in the room of the five hindrances, the mind is in the door of cessation;
Leaning on the house of impermanence, the mind contemplates the protection of skillful means;ğŸ”½Sitting on the ground of a poisonous snake, the mind thinks of the path to abandon and distance;
Riding a fragile boat on dangerous waters, the mind plans the way to save oneself;
Approaching a forest of raging fire, the mind considers the peace of extinguishing it.
Therefore, the enlightened one practices the skillful means of wisdom, and pulls oneself out of the difficulties of birth and death;
Cutting off thoughts of the three realms, one goes to the land of nirvana.
Having practiced oneself, one also teaches others. This is called the meaning of the practice of the six virtues of extensive wisdom.
As for what you asked before, the TathÄgata's supernatural powers, the marks and virtues, which are immeasurable, how does one attain them?

By practicing these six dharmas, various wisdoms, concentrations, thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, and boundless and bottomless practices, one attains the title of Buddha, the Heavenly Honored One, and is able to do anything.
Then, upon hearing the Heavenly Honored One's teachings, the assembly all raised their voices, vowing to give rise to the unsurpassed, supreme, and equal intention.
They all said:
Today we have gained great blessings, enabling all people to quickly attain this practice.

At that time, Good Illumination attained the four pure dharmas: first, the purity of the eyes; second, the purity of the body; third, the purity of speech; and fourth, the purity of the mind. He joyfully lowered his head and silently contemplated the meaning of the Dharma.
Then, Good Illumination moved aside from his seat, knelt for a long time, and addressed the TathÄgata, saying:

The teachings spoken by the Heavenly Honored One extensively liberate without limit. The Dharma prohibitions are subtle, restraining the mind's tendencies, subduing the mind and turning it towards purity. Calamities and defilements are eliminated. The merit of those who hear this is already great, let alone those who practice it, whose virtue is difficult to fathom.

The Honored One of Heaven also said, In the past, not only did he practice these six things, but he also practiced the Dharma of concentration and the boundless thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, and then accomplished the Buddha's work, the four fearlessnesses, the ten powers, and the eighteen extraordinary and wondrous dharmas, with mastery over transformation, speaking without difficulty, and personally seeing the Buddhas, flying to the ten directions to bestow liberation on all those who have not yet crossed over, leading and transforming them to liberation;
Destroying the heretical teachings, guiding the crooked and deviant;
Being born in the midst of suffering, yet not attached or cut off, by not being attached or cut off, creating causes and conditions, teaching those who are confused.
Such wondrous virtues, countless practices, by what kind of concentration can one attain them?
I only wish that the Honored One of Heaven!
For those who are present now and in the future, expound its profound meaning, enabling them to attain liberation.
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
The questions you wish to ask, I will now explain in detail, laying out the great essentials. Listen attentively.
Yes, he replied.
I will listen to the teaching, said the Buddha.
There is a meditative absorption called 'Accomplishing Complete Illumination.'
If there are people who hear of it and are able to practice it for one day up to seven days, the merit and blessings they attain are beyond analogy.

Those who hear this teaching have already made offerings to hundreds of thousands of koá¹­Ä«s of Buddhas in past lives, and have heard it without doubt while sitting in their presence. In this life, they will once again encounter this meditative absorption of 'Accomplishing Complete Illumination.'

Now, if they are able to practice it for even the time it takes to snap one's fingers, they will be permanently freed from the three evil destinies, their merit will gradually be fulfilled, and they will quickly attain Buddhahood.
The various matters you asked about can all be accomplished.
Sumati said:
How many practices must be carried out to attain this exalted meditative absorption?
The Buddha said:
One must purify one hundred and thirty-five practices in order to enter this meditative absorption.

Far from bodily actions, free from verbal faults, eliminating mental thoughts, ending the three defilements, warding off the six afflictions, blocking the five hindrances, the twelve links of dependent origination are already exhausted, unravelling the bonds, illuminating the sixty-two contemplations.

Healing many wounds, delighting many afflictions, abandoning the great, discarding bones and blood, avoiding relatives, severing all habits, cutting off desires, having nothing desirable or undesirable, scraping away the defilements of greed, cutting off the roots of desire, not being confused by the current, being able to control illness, not conceiving of self, being without non-self, establishing the four beliefs, abiding in the four cessations, engaging in the four abandonments, planting the five faculties, cultivating the five powers, understanding the seven knowledges, practicing the eight right paths, entering the eight mindfulnesses, the eight constant efforts, having already no efforts to practice, leaving what cannot be practiced.

Studying the highest wisdom, respecting oneself, not being arrogant but gentle and soft, raining the Dharma rain, not thinking of two things in one Dharma, not thinking of three things, not thinking of useless things, not thinking of the boundless, not thinking of emptiness, not thinking of thoughts, not thinking of a place, not dwelling in the thought of no place.

Well knowing the Buddha's knowledge and purity, having already known purity and well studied, the mind abides correctly, not turning back wrongly, equating good and evil, like light and darkness, knowing light and darkness are both empty, not doubting the Dharma, not taking purity to be non-existence, contemplating existence and non-existence as one.

Having already known one and eliminated one, not giving rise to thoughts about one, diligently accepting teachings, well practicing, due to practice entering the boundless, practicing superior intentions, not listening to the mind, skillfully guarding consciousness, not being confused or turned around.
Coming and going three times without attachment, observing all natures and thoroughly knowing they have no basis, knowing the basisless cannot be fulfilled, using the unfulfilled to regulate oneself.

Contemplating the Dharma as the same as emptiness, eternally abiding, uninterrupted, and without thought, transcending permanence and impermanence, not thinking of people, not forgiving the world, not attached to things, abandoning seeking, the Dharma combining and separating with nothing to see, the body arising and perishing all due to transformation, knowing the Dharma equally in the superior, middling, and inferior, thus passing from this world to the next.

Contemplating the two causes as empty space, the mind without desire yet always kind, practicing purity and skillfully guiding people, knowing people's inclinations and turning them away from turbidity, purifying within turbidity, the mind far from affection and entering the fire, using the pure fire to burn away the many defilements, having extinguished defilements and being tranquil and pure, not thinking of good or evil, not thinking of beauty or ugliness, not thinking of suffering or happiness, without joy or anger at praise or blame, the mind disciplined and pure wherever it goes, opening the great treasury and entering the great Dharma, protecting the full Dharma with the path and precepts, diligently practicing the contemplation of suffering and its arising.

Using the path of exhaustion as illumination, observing the arising of all natures and consciousnesses, stopping the darkness of flowing and binding thoughts, diligently seeking cessation to enter the path.

Cutting off three cravings, eliminating four faults, increasing four cities, leaving five coverings, severing six arrogances, cultivating six respects, perfecting six Dharma realizations, practicing seven wisdoms, strengthening eight powers, uprooting nine bonds, practicing nine cessations, and cultivating the ten vast purities as one's own abilities, the ten powers and wisdom already fully equipped, no longer studying the ten straight Dharma practices, the Dharma seeds always abiding, already fully equipped in the Three Jewels, using the Dharma to give without extreme exhaustion, fully practicing all the specialized abilities, entering non-attachment, entering emptiness without slacking, turning away from thoughts of self, having no concept of self, no calculation of person, tranquil like nirvana.
These are the one hundred and thirty-five matters that accomplish the practice of the precepts of the samÄdhi of complete illumination.

When the Buddha spoke this chapter on the Dharma of precepts for the concentration of the light of perfect adornment, three hundred thousand bright beings attained this concentration, perfected the merit of adornment, and stood on the tenth ground.

SubhÅ«ti then attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, and the five hundred people in the same assembly, their minds delighted, all gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed, supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Four hundred thousand bright beings all stood in the practice of irreversibility.
Fifty thousand people in the evil assembly all attained the path of non-attachment.
Two thousand virtuous men and women who upheld the five precepts all attained the practice of leaving traces.
The gods in the sky made music.
They praised, saying:
Excellent!
The people of the world have now attained the essentials of the supreme teachings. Those who are foolish, deluded, and turbid have today suddenly had all their impurities removed.
Like washing away dirt with clean water, now that they have heard the great Dharma, their mental impurities have been eliminated.
We wish for the wheel of the Dharma to always turn, enabling all to quickly attain wondrous wisdom.
We have always encountered the Heavenly Honored One, and our births are not apart from him.
We will quickly attain this complete and bright concentration, and will widely proclaim the grace of the Dharma, illuminating and guiding the dark and confused.
Like today's great assembly, we will establish countless foundations of the Way.
SubhÅ«ti said to the Buddha:
Now hearing this concentration from the Heavenly Honored One, with a pure mind I contemplate my lack of wisdom, and I do not know where it is, either externally or internally, it is also like this.
The Buddha told SubhÅ«ti:

It is like entering a dark room with a torch, then not knowing where the darkness is. This concentration method, if one is able to practice the path and complete the equipment, then one does not know where the twelve links of ignorance are lost.
SubhÅ«ti!

Not only that, then one does not see the place of arising and ceasing of birth and death in the ten directions, up to practicing the traces without attachment, the causes and conditions of the enlightened Buddha, up to the TathÄgata, all without seeing anything, seeing is not seeing.
No thoughts, all pure thoughts, thoughts of cessation and purity, and also not thoughts of cessation and purity, this is the empty view of nothing to see.
Summing up, he said to the World-Honored One:
How is it that not thoughts of cessation and purity are the empty view?
At that time, where is the mind?
What is seen?
The Buddha said:
Summing up,

at that time, the mind is not in the internal, not in the external, not in the path, not in the mundane, not in existence, not in non-existence, not in arising, not in cessation, not in a place of movement.
This mind has no root, no sound, and should be seen like this when thoroughly sought from the beginning.
This view is a view, emptiness, cessation, and a definite method of having nothing whatsoever.
Using this as the view, a clear person should think like this, remove thoughts and go to purity.
Those who contemplate in this way will attain the teaching of the samÄdhi of complete illumination.
This Dharma is a Dharma of non-existence, and its name is forcefully given to it.

When the wise hear this, they should not be surprised or doubtful, but should contemplate this Dharma with sincerity, without retreating or slacking off. This is already attaining the power of protection from the majestic spiritual power of samÄdhi.
SubhÅ«ti!
Those who wish to study this should practice the four things and gradually enter the realm of non-seeing.
He said:
What are the four?
First, not having a body, second, not having a dwelling, third, not having the world, fourth, not having objects.
Those who are able to do this will attain entry into the four essentials.
He said:
What are the four essentials?
He said:
First, the essential of the Buddha, second, the essential of the Dharma, third, the essential of emptiness, fourth, the essential of cessation.
These are called the four essentials.
The Buddha then praised:
Without the notion of self, without the notion of non-self, also not without discernment;
Not attached to the twelve links of dependent arising, this accords with perfect completion.
This concentration is originally non-existent, not a place of existence or establishment;
Out of compassion for the world, its name is manifested, and its practice of emptiness also accords with propriety.
The human mind, along with mental consciousness, these three are the arising dharmas;
Practicing this accords with perfect completion, without arising and without ceasing.
Emptiness is the ground of perfect completion, free from the suffering of birth and death;
All without remainder, this accords with the practice of concentration.
Worldly people rely on each other, with wrong views and attachment to famous dharmas;
Greedily clinging to the notion of permanence, bound and constrained for countless lifetimes.
Accumulating practices, always obstructed, with worries and attachments weighing down the mind;
The four transformations follow like a shadow, coming and going without rest.
Practicing concentration without reliance, correctly observing without attachment to names;
The thought of greed is exhausted and extinguished, understanding and liberation are pure and at ease.
Pure conduct is unobstructed by delusion, and the deluded and troubled mind is completely gone;
Birth, old age, and sickness are already severed, and there is no more worry of coming and going.
The eye of wisdom is already greatly bright, and the root of wisdom is boundless and bottomless;
Wisdom leads to the other shore, and by practicing concentration one attains this.
The stars, fire, and the bright moon, the sun, and the light of Mount Kunlun;
The illumination of the palaces of Åšakra and BrahmÄ, this concentration's brightness surpasses them all.
The Buddha told Sumati:
Innumerable eons ago, there was a Buddha named Venerable Conqueror of Desire King.

At that time, the Buddha lived for 100,000 years. He did not stay in South India, but in the north, in the Pure Radiance Heaven, where the Buddha resided. That country is 30 million Buddha-lands away from here.
At the time of Venerable Fo Yuwang Buddha, the human lifespan was 20,000 years, and he always had 600,000 disciples who were self-reliant, and the number of wise ones was immeasurable.

The people were prosperous, abundant, and peaceful, and they were mostly virtuous in conduct, with the virtue of precepts towering above them, and the three defilements of desire and greed were thin and flourishing.

At that time, the Buddha had a great assembly of wise ones from the ten directions, who universally accepted and upheld this Chengju Guangming Samadhi, and then accomplished the Buddha's work, being one of the four cardinal directions.

At that time, there was an elder's son named Minjian, who was 500 years old and was considered a youth by the people of the country at that time.ğŸ”½Minjian heard of the Buddha's great assembly and then told his parents, asking to go and see the Buddha to observe what he was doing.

His parents allowed him to go, and he immediately went to see the Buddha, bowed his head to the ground, finished paying respects, stood properly, and with a joyful mind, immediately took off the precious and various jeweled necklaces from his body and scattered them over the Buddha;
By the Buddha's spiritual power, the scattered flowers instantly transformed into flower canopies covering the great assembly, each person having their own.
The Buddha told them to sit down and expounded the Dharma of the SamantaprabhÄsa SamÄdhi. Their minds became even more joyful and they vowed:
May we always encounter this SamantaprabhÄsa SamÄdhi in our future lives, be able to practice it quickly, and not violate the precepts and virtues.
At that time, the young man made offerings with all kinds of treasures and made an utmost vow with a single word. For this reason, he immediately received it in his future lives.
Sumati!
Do you know who the young man was at that time?
It was you!
Now that I have appeared in the world, you have encountered the samÄdhi again.
From now on, you will certainly attain it before long;
after attaining wisdom, in two hundred kalpas you will fully become a buddha, called the King Who Guides the World.
The sole honored one in heaven and on earth, you will guide the ignorant like I do now.

When Sumati heard the Buddha bestow upon him the title of a future Buddha, his mind became pure and his body light, like a beryl crystal, clean inside and out, without any impurities. Wherever he placed his feet, he purified his mind in the same way. He then attained ten tranquil states:

First, to be tranquil and not be moved by what one sees; second, to be always content with the affairs of various troubles; third, to be tranquil and not think about various thoughts; fourth, to be tranquil and abandon the affairs that the common people enjoy; fifth, to be tranquil and not think of seeking or not seeking virtue and non-virtue; sixth, to be tranquil and not attached to good and evil dharmas; seventh, to be tranquil and not expect honor from the humble and the virtuous; eighth, to be tranquil and have no joy or anger in abandoning respect and support; ninth, to be tranquil and have the same origin as all dharmas, whether lost or not; tenth, to be able to transform with the Dharma in a pure and tranquil place, as if in an impure place, and to be tranquil and unattached, without thoughts of separation or abandonment.
With a mind like this, he then said:
Heavenly Venerable!

Now, the essentials of bestowing official titles and ranks upon me, I will repay my gratitude by proclaiming and opening up to all, so that those who have not heard will hear, those who do not know will know, and those who have not crossed over will be liberated.
I have been in birth and death for a long time, and although it is much and long, I do not consider it troublesome.

I am already unattached, already awakened, already able to be disciplined, already able to be unconfused, already able to enter their robes, and I show it according to conditions. I am not already in birth and death for the sake of birth and death. I have already fully understood the Buddha's majestic spiritual power.

I have five hundred people like me. I wish that the World-Honored One would add the great compassion of the four equalities, encourage them to enter the Dharma, and quickly understand this complete bright and radiant samÄdhi.

Then the Buddha smiled, and they all saw light coming out from his mouth, with five colors shining brightly, illuminating the ten directions - those who were in pain all temporarily found peace - and then returning to enter from the top of his head, as if it were his usual radiance.
The attendant Ä€nanda adjusted his robe, moved his seat, put his palms together, and said:
The Buddha never smiles without reason. When he smiles, there must be a purpose.
I only wish that you would explain it and spread the word to those who have not yet heard it.
Then Ä€nanda sighed and said:
The face of the heroic countenance, eyes, nose, and mouth are upright and proper;
The golden body is extremely soft and fine, now smiling, what great joy!
The square mouth contains white teeth, the lips resemble the brightness of red fire;
The beauty of eighty kinds, now smiling must have a reason.
The mirror teeth are forty, the broad tongue and cheeks are square;
When speaking, fragrant air is emitted, now smiling, for whom is it accomplished?
The eyebrows and beard are dark blue, the two eyelids are proper;
The white tuft stands in the heavens, now smiling, I only wish to hear.
The heavenly eye has already become clear, the eye of the Way has already been fully penetrated;
The eye of the Dharma and the eye of wisdom, these four have already been fully accomplished.
The smile must have a response, revealing the transformation to the incomplete;
Or it will receive the oath, therefore smiling, the golden countenance is emitted.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
The Buddha's truth is not false laughter!

Now, the five hundred wise ones who follow Sumati have already made offerings to two billion buddhas in past lives. They have heard this accomplishment of the light of wisdom in one hundred and thirty-five lines while sitting in those places. Since they first heard it, they have passed through many lifetimes, but they have always been fierce and only counted small virtues. They have not been able to subdue their minds and uphold the purest and most wonderful meditative practices.
Although this is so, due to the merit of hearing it, they will not be born in the three evil realms and will always encounter this honored meditative dharma.
Today, they have come to the assembly, listened and accepted it with a pure mind, and gradually explained and entered the correct truth.
Later, when Maitreya Buddha appears, they will attain this accomplishment of the light of meditative concentration.
After thirty-six myriads of koá¹­is of kalpas, they will all become buddhas.

They will further teach this Dharma to those they rule, each with their own title. One is called King Banner-Pillar Radiance, the next is called Great Light Pervading and Manifesting, the next is called Great Power Subduing Evil, the next is called Fierce and Powerful, the next is called Flowing Water Pure Sound, the next is called High Virtue Universally Connecting, the next is called Manifestation of the Present Eradicating Bonds, the next is called Transforming Illusions Freely, and each has their own name.
Then, the five hundred wise ones, having heard the predictions they would receive, rejoiced and leaped with joy, and attained the five irreversible minds:
First, the mind of seeking blessings through sacrifices does not turn to other paths;
Second, all the five flavors, whether acceptable or not, are the divine lives of sentient beings, and they will never turn to harming living beings for their own palate;
Third, they will firmly establish the practice of the unsurpassed and unique honored one, and will never waver or abandon it to follow the lesser paths;

Fourth, knowing that this Dharma is respected and has no equal, diligently practicing with a focused mind, even if there are other dharmas that are mixed and false, one observes one's own dharma separately and never turns to them;

Fifth, even if the world has Buddhas or not, the Dharma flourishes or declines, has an end or is cut off, the mind remains in concentration, and one does not turn to deviant practices because of the absence of these Three Jewels.
These are the five unchangeable minds.
Having attained these mental dharmas, they all knelt before the Venerable One and said:
The Buddha has compassion for us!
Announce our conferred titles and the names of our future Buddhahood, and we will repay our gratitude.

Later, if we are born in a degenerate world, we will diligently practice the right way, uphold and proclaim the Venerable One's Dharma, enlighten those who do not know, correct those who are confused, encourage the lazy, help those who are discouraged, fill in the gaps and fears of those who are incomplete, illuminate those who are in darkness, and untie those who are bound.

For those who kill, he spoke of the misfortune of dying young; for those who steal, he spoke of the suffering of poverty and begging; for those who engage in sexual misconduct, he spoke of the calamities of the body; for those who slander and deceive, he spoke of the danger of destroying their nature; for those who are intoxicated and confused, he spoke of the danger of harming their bodies.
Today, we all vow before the Buddha to establish five vows and practice as bright beings until we attain Buddhahood, practicing without rest.
We pray that the Buddha will have compassion for us!
Listen to what we say.
The first vow is:
When we practice as bright beings, may we quickly transform our bodies and roam throughout the ten directions.
If there is no Buddha in the world, and if there are disciples of the four groups who know the Dharma, they may say:
'Believe that there truly is a Buddha, but he has just entered nirvana.
' Laypeople with wrong views will give rise to a net of doubts, not seeing the Buddha or knowing the Dharma, and they will say:
'There is no Buddha, it is all just empty falsehood!
If there really is a Buddha, why can't we see his majestic spiritual power?'
The two disputes are like this.

When there is a dispute, I will go and transform, manifesting the Buddha's body with excellent characteristics illuminating, and also transforming with majestic spiritual power, causing the two disputing people to see and know that there is a Buddha, and saying to them:
'Do not doubt!'
The doubting person will then be startled and delighted, and I will speak the Dharma for them and teach them to be liberated. Having done so, I will then transform and leave, like this, endlessly.
The second vow is:
The Buddha has the great, wonderful, extremely profound, immeasurable Dharma gates of the twelve divisions.

After the Buddha's nirvana, the disciples each study one sutra, only seeing one scroll, and cannot fully understand, not yet understanding the four explanations and the equality of skillful means, and then they turn to argue with each other.

Some say it is empty, some say it exists, some say this meaning is so, some say it is not so. The one who truly knows the Dharma and its meaning speaks with characteristics, but the one who does not understand the meaning is greedy for names and adorns characteristics as if understanding. Then in the assembly, two disputes arise, giving rise to anger and abandoning good to pursue evil.

When there is such a dispute, I will go and manifest a transformation body surpassing the assembly, causing the assembly to be awestruck, and then explain and cut off the dispute, distinguishing the correct one.
Pulling the sutra and explaining it, causing both sides to rejoice, and then transforming and leaving, like this without end.
The third vow is:

After the Buddha's nirvana, laypeople and scholars of external knowledge enter the great assembly of the Buddha's disciples. The disciples discuss the meaning of the Dharma, speak of the various paths, distinguish the deviant and the correct, and classify the high and low, then saying:
'Among the ninety-six kinds of paths, is the Buddha the most honored?'
There are four spiritual powers of flying and transforming, and none in the heavens above or the world below is equal to the Buddha's wisdom.
' The worldly wise ones, who were not born to see the Buddha, practiced wrong views, believed in the lesser and slandered the great, and said to the Buddha's disciples:
'You should not speak falsely, saying that the Buddha has spiritual powers of flying and transforming. Since ancient times, among the various types of people, there has never been such a thing.

It is not true.' At that time, I then transformed into the Buddha's body, showing the various excellent marks, manifesting the spiritual powers, walking in the sky, emitting fire and water from the body, causing the worldly people and the worldly wise ones to be awestruck and surprised, and only then did they know the transformation of the majestic spirit.
Considering it to be the Dharma teaching, they were given the correct precepts, and only then did the transformation disappear, like this, endlessly.
The fourth vow is:
If a person reads and recites the Buddha's sutras, either alone in a wild room, or in the mountains, or in a great country,
The noble-born elder and the people had no teacher's method, or the teacher was unclear, stubborn, and had nothing to ask, so their minds were full of doubts.

I transformed into an ascetic, put on robes and went to them, explaining point by point, distinguishing the beginning and end, skillfully opening up the doubtful mind, causing them to enter the subtle without any doubts or difficulties.
Then I transformed and left, like this, endlessly.
The fifth vow is:
Wherever I am born, I will always encounter the Buddha.
After the Buddha's nirvana, his disciples will establish temples, depict images of the Buddha's form, and set up lecture halls to discuss the scriptures and Dharma.
If one is a layperson, opening up the study of minor wisdom, bound in the four inverted views,

Hearing the Buddha's disciples expound the teachings for transcending the world and the essentials of birth and death, they would go to refute and slander the true and correct, seeking fame and victory, or adding vexation and anger, wanting to go and destroy, belittling and disparaging the humble and weak, obstructing the correct path and preventing its practice.
At that time, I would then transform and manifest the Buddha's body and further expound for them the most wonderful Dharma.
Displaying the consequences of birth and death, blessings and misfortunes, I would lead them to the heavens to observe the hall of blessings;
Pulling them to the hells, I would have them witness the retribution for offenses.
Shaking them with the power of the Dharma and subduing them with the power of wisdom, I would cause them to immediately submit and have faith in the great path.
Having done so, I would then transform and depart, like this, endlessly.
As I become a bright person and attain Buddhahood, I will always carry out these five vows without rest.
I pray that the Heavenly Honored One, with the blessings of great kindness, will cover and bless us, allowing us to attain our aspirations.
Thereupon, the Buddha said:
Excellent aspiration!
This will be accomplished by the wise ones, and what they should aspire to will henceforth certainly not be lost.
But they should always protect their practice and not allow it to be damaged or leaked.
Strive to lead all to quickly attain your aspirations.
The Buddha then praised:
The great aspiration is the foremost, transforming delusions with these five;
One will accomplish countless, and the doubtful will enter the path.
This virtue is immeasurable, being the essence of all practices;
If one hears this aspiration, the net of doubt will be forever removed.
The five aspirations are the ground of Buddhahood, and what is subdued accords with the transformation of the path;
Great wisdom has no fault beyond this, this aspiration is supreme among people.
The five hundred wise ones, their aspirations are few and equal;
In future lives, they will attain and not lose, and receive blessings and joy from all.
The Buddha said to all the wise ones and those sitting in the assembly:
This is the true principle. You should diligently practice it. You should take being fully equipped as the basis, and not take empty words and frivolous speech as being in accord with the Dharma.

You should endure and not do evil. Whether in solitude or in a large assembly, in places of honor or humility, restrain your mind and make it accord with the precepts, and do not violate the practice of mindfulness even in leisure and entertainment;
Do not be arrogant in the assembly;
Do not be arrogant and haughty because of high status;
Do not be swayed by low status and weakness;
Do not be ashamed of good, do not be ashamed of evil;
Do not plant fruitless things;
The mind is like the true Dharma, without wavering;
Do not give rise to thoughts of increase or decrease.
Such a bright person, whose five good roots and wishes will surely attain their aspirations, will quickly accomplish supreme enlightenment.
At that time, the bright person King of No-Defilement stepped down from his seat, knelt for a long time, and said to the Heavenly Honored One:

I wish that the Buddha would manifest the majestic spiritual power of this perfected luminous samÄdhi today, so that this assembly can see it and be delighted and joyful. They will all arouse the mind and establish this basis of virtue. Those who are not yet accomplished will be accomplished, and those who are not yet liberated will be liberated.
At that time, there was a bright being in the assembly named Great Strength Universal Level.
The Buddha praised Great Strength Universal Level:
Manifest the majestic spiritual power of this perfected luminous samÄdhi.

Immediately accepting the teaching, he did not move from his seat, and then entered the wisdom samÄdhi of the still mind. In the time it takes to snap one's fingers, the small and large mountains, the great obstructing mountains, and the small obstructing mountains in the trichiliocosm all disappeared and were no longer visible. Everything became completely level, with the color of dark beryl.
Moreover, he caused the lands of the buddhas in the ten directions to all be able to see each other, as if they were a mere one fathom away.
He observed the seats of the buddhas in the ten directions, as if gazing up at the stars, beyond count.
He then raised with his right hand the worlds of the ten directions and the trichiliocosm, placing them on a single fingertip, and lowered them, as if lifting a single dust mote.
Among the people and wriggling creatures, there was no one who knew this, yet they had the thought of being frightened.
Then, he again placed all the worlds of the ten directions within a square vessel one chi in size, without crowding them.
After manifesting the transformation, it was as if nothing had happened.
Those who were present all saw this and were astonished and delighted, giving rise to great vows, and their minds were all in the stage of the unsurpassed, solitary honored one.
Eight million bright people and the honored gods attained the samÄdhi of blissful wisdom.
Furthermore, six hundred thousand people all entered the Dharma gate of penetrating understanding.
Furthermore, sixty-eight thousand people attained the samÄdhi of the radiant concentration of perfection.
The bright people who came from the ten directions were all delighted.
The Buddha said to Sumati:
The reason why all people do not study this perfection of light samÄdhi is because they dwell in delusion.
If one considers existence to be existent, one will then become attached to black darkness. Dwelling in attachment is like walking in the dark night with eyes closed, then one will see nothing.
Seeing nothing means not being aware of the good and evil one currently creates in this life.
Because of not being aware of what one sees, one then sighs and weeps, thinking that one does good but receives evil retribution, or that one previously did evil but receives good blessings.

Not understanding the basis of this, one becomes entangled in doubt. Already entangled in doubt, one does not wish to study what can be studied, does not wish to progress what can be advanced, and does not wish to enter what can be entered. Therefore, one loses this samÄdhi, cries and grieves, and wanders for countless eons without end. Having come and gone without rest, this is called the practice of toil and suffering.ğŸ”½Alas!
Good understanding!

Because this chapter can be used as a model, the Buddha appears in the world precisely for the sake of ignorant and deluded people. If there are people who study this right concentration, the afflictions of birth and death that they encounter will all be quickly eliminated;
And they will be able to instruct and guide all those who are attached to existence.
SubhÅ«ti!
You should always contemplate the Dharma of emptiness and not dwell in places of delusion and error.
SubhÅ«ti said to the Buddha:

If there are wise people born into a family of rank and nobility, who govern the county and hold official positions, and whose minds are often disturbed and unable to be focused, wishing to study this concentration, what should they do?
The Buddha said:

If a wise person has the causes and conditions of holding official positions in the county, or is in an unstable place, wishing to study this concentration but unable to focus the mind, they should write out this sutra and make offerings to it.
Set up a pavilion, burn incense, pay homage, and during the day, concentrate the mind without missing the three periods, bowing with the head and face, with sincere and utmost sincerity.
There are also fifteen practices to be added:
First, do not kill;
Second, give life;
Third, do not take what is not given;
Fourth, show kindness to others;
Fifth, do not engage in sexual misconduct;
Sixth, stay away from sensual pleasures;
Seventh, do not deceive or flatter;
Eighth, speak truthfully and give good advice;
Ninth, do not get drunk;
Tenth, do not give alcohol as a gift;
Eleventh, protect the weak and prevent them from being wronged;
Twelfth, when encountering life, show kindness and let each one find its place;
Thirteenth, be magnanimous and accept those of inferior character, teaching them with the right Dharma;
Fourteenth, those who come to you and make complaints must be responded to justly and fairly according to the law, without any injustice or anger;
Fifteenth, use goodness to encourage those above and bestow it on the people, without slacking off from beginning to end.
Practice these fifteen precepts, do not neglect them, this is also the teaching of concentration, you will surely attain it and later attain liberation.
Summing up, the Buddha said:

If there are ordinary people who are dragged by past offenses, in an uneasy place, constrained and obstructed, who have the aspiration to accomplish the complete and bright concentration method, but are unable to follow their own thoughts and wishes, wanting to study this honored concentration, what should they do?ğŸ”½The Buddha said:
Summing up, the Buddha said:
Ordinary people who sincerely want to study are also as explained above.
Write out this sutra, set up a pavilion, burn incense and pay homage, do not miss the three periods of time, and should further add ten practices:
First, cultivate and uphold the five precepts, without any transgression;
Second, in leisure time, gradually recite and practice the concentration method text;
Third, although engaged in work, recite and practice in the inner mind, causing no forgetfulness or error;
Fourth, when in a place of hard work and suffering, one should know that it is due to past actions, and not be resentful;
Fifth, if living in a place without Buddha images or those who are free from evil, always keep them in mind and pay homage in the four directions, as if facing the Buddha without difference;
Sixth, be careful and gentle, harmonize the mind, and be humble to all;
Seventh, do things to the fullest extent without pretense;
Eighth, make friends equally, not favoring strength;
Ninth, if seeing the old, weak, sick, or emaciated, feel pity and protect them, with sincerity and no pretense;
Tenth, always take refuge in the Three Jewels without being lazy or forgetful;
These are the ten things.

Even if an ordinary person is in a place of hard work and constraint, they should practice these ten things, not defiling or slacking off, and should also teach the Dharma with a focused mind, not losing it in life after life, and eventually attaining liberation.
Subhuti said to the Buddha:
If there are virtuous women,
in families of noble lineage, who due to the circumstances of their household duties cannot leave, and wish to study this complete and bright samÄdhi, what should they do?
The Buddha said:
Good understanding!
If women, due to the circumstances of their household duties, wish to study this true samÄdhi, it is also as explained above.

They should write out this sÅ«tra well, set up shelves, offer banners and flowers, burn incense and pay homage, touch their heads to the ground, and at the three times of cockcrow, midday, and midnight, pay homage without fail, with utmost sincerity and always wishing to be free from a woman's body, their minds cutting off lustful desires, and be diligent in this way.
Moreover, they should engage in twenty practices:
First, uphold the fifteen precepts of the superior person, the ten precepts of the middling person, without violating them;
Second, abandon jealous thoughts;ğŸ”½Third, reduce the fondness for bracelets and anklets;
Fourth, remove the adornments of oil and powder;
Fifth, they are free from indulgence;
Sixth, their clothing is genuine and not extravagant;
Seventh, they raise their children in the inner quarters with a compassionate heart;
Eighth, they gently instruct their servants without resorting to harsh punishment;
Ninth, they take care of the orphaned and ensure equal distribution of clothing and food;
Tenth, they serve their superiors with filial piety and treat those below them with kindness;
Eleventh, they lower their voice and humility, always admonishing and being cautious;
Twelfth, they are humble and obedient, always knowing shame and modesty;
Thirteenth, in their actions, they hold to purity and cleanliness, offering it to their parents-in-law, parents, and the Three Jewels, as well as to teachers and friends;
Fourteenth, they treat both the close and distant, the good and the evil, with kindness and equality, without these four thoughts of discrimination;
Fifteenth, even when alone in private, their mind does not think of desire;
Sixteenth, they are upright, sincere, and single-minded, always keeping the Dharma in mind;
Seventeenth, whatever you wish to do, report to your superiors and then act;
Eighteenth, be without a self-important mind, always humbly instruct your body to be in accordance with the true Dharma;
Nineteenth, never peek over walls, have deviant thoughts;
Twentieth, sitting, standing, and speaking, never be frivolous, always in accordance with the Dharma, without slight faults.
This is the Dharma of virtuous women living at home practicing right concentration.
In this way, the merit gradually fills up, and later one attains liberation.
SubhÅ«ti said to the Buddha:

If there are women of a small family who enjoy virtuous conduct by nature, but are poor and in distress, with difficult and arduous duties, worried about clothing and food, unable to be free, inwardly weary of suffering and sin, wishing to be quickly liberated, having heard this complete and bright honored concentration of pure Dharma, wishing to practice it with utmost sincerity, what should they do?
The Buddha said:
SubhÅ«ti!

For such ordinary women who are in poverty and hardship, even if they cannot fully practice the precepts while studying this samÄdhi, they should still cultivate and uphold ten matters without violating them.
First, they should personally approach virtuous friends and receive the five precepts, practicing without violation;
Second, even if hungry or cold, they should endure not killing or stealing to satisfy themselves;
Third, even if living alone, they should endure not engaging in sexual misconduct, frequently admonishing their thoughts;
Fourth, even if poor, they should endure not deceiving or being lazy in seeking wealth;
Fifth, they should endure not watching performances at wine, food, or entertainment establishments;
Sixth, they should regard those who uphold the practice of samÄdhi as if they were the Buddha;
Seventh, they should always practice five wholesome thoughts:
First, the thought of giving; second, the thought of respect; third, the thought of propriety; fourth, the thought of being humble to all; fifth, the thought of subduing various bad tendencies;
Eighth, even when engaged in work, they recite the Dharma texts in their minds without laziness;
Ninth, on the six monthly observance days, they enter the pagoda to pay homage to the Three Jewels;

Tenth, although they may not have money and wealth to give as offerings, they always personally sweep and sprinkle the pagoda grounds, provide clean water and refreshments to the assembly of monks, and give their strength as an offering, diligently without weariness.

These are the ten things that an ordinary woman, even in poverty, should practice without laziness. She will then be exalted, and in her next life, she will encounter the Buddha and always meet the definitive Dharma, and in the end, she will attain liberation.
The Buddha said:
Subhamitra!

The virtuous women I speak of, whether of noble or ordinary birth, whether of virtuous or ordinary conduct, the four types of practice, the precepts are clearly understood. If one's body practices them without fault or leakage, the blessings and virtues of this are difficult to compare with.
